input.outputFormat: #Motivating Example

input.code:
### Motivating Example
Assume we have 2 relations:

1. Document - Word matrix \\( Y^{(1)} \in ( \Re \cup \lbrace ? \rbrace )^{n\times F} \\)
2. Document - Label matrix  \\( Y^{(2)} \in \lbrace 0,1,? \rbrace ^{n\times K} \\)

Representing is a a 2-slices tensor is overly complicated and not needed.
A simple and effective way to represent it is by concatenating the two matrices into a big \\( n\times (F+K) \\) matrix:

\\( Y := [ Y^{(1)} \ Y^{(2)}]  \\)

We can estimate a probabilitic model on \\(Y\\) by factorizing it.

Just use the binary matrix factorization technique we saw before. This is a new method for supervised classification!

 - Handles missing data in the input
 - Can work with partially labelled documents
 - Takes advantage of unlabelled data
input.outputFormat:
Motivating Example

Assume we have 2 relations:

  1. Document - Word matrix Y(1)∈(ℜ∪{?})n×F
  2. Document - Label matrix Y(2)∈{0,1,?}n×K

Representing is a a 2-slices tensor is overly complicated and not needed. A simple and effective way to represent it is by concatenating the two matrices into a big n×(F+K) matrix:

Y:=[Y(1) Y(2)]

We can estimate a probabilitic model on Y by factorizing it.

Just use the binary matrix factorization technique we saw before. This is a new method for supervised classification!

  • Handles missing data in the input
  • Can work with partially labelled documents
  • Takes advantage of unlabelled data
#Motivating example - continued

input.code:
### Motivating Example
We have more information. We want to add a relation corresponding to labelled features:

3. Word - Label matrix \\( Y^{(3)} \in \lbrace 0, 1 ,? \rbrace ^{F\times K} \\)

By concatenation, we have a \\( (n + F) \times (F+K) \\) matrix:

\\( Y := \begin{array}{cc} 
Y^{(1)} & Y^{(2)} \\
Y^{(3)} & [?]_{F\times F} 
\end{array}  \\)

We can estimate a probabilitic model on \\(Y\\) by factorizing it. This additional relation enables feature labelling and increase prediction capabilities when similar rare words share similar labels.
input.outputFormat:
Motivating Example

We have more information. We want to add a relation corresponding to labelled features:

  1. Word - Label matrix Y(3)∈{0,1,?}F×K

By concatenation, we have a (n+F)×(F+K) matrix:

Y:=Y(1)Y(2) Y(3)[?]F×F

We can estimate a probabilitic model on Y by factorizing it. This additional relation enables feature labelling and increase prediction capabilities when similar rare words share similar labels.
#Motivating Example - Final

input.code:
### Motivating Example
Something is missing: the labels of the words and of the documents are the same, but the model does not use this information.

We will create a \\( (n + F + K) \times (n + F + K) \\) symmetric matrix:

\\( Y := \begin{array}{cc} 
[?]_{n\times n} Y^{(1)} & Y^{(2)} \\
Y^{(1)T} & [?]_{F\times F} & Y^{(3)T} \\ 
Y^{(2)T} & Y^{(3)} & [?]_{K\times K}
\end{array}  \\)

We can estimate a probabilitic model on \\(Y\\) by factorizing it. This duplication of data enables the factorization to use the data from both document and word in the label embeddings.
input.outputFormat:
Motivating Example

Something is missing: the labels of the words and of the documents are the same, but the model does not use this information.

We will create a (n+F+K)×(n+F+K) symmetric matrix:

Y:=[?]n×nY(1)Y(2) Y(1)T[?]F×FY(3)T Y(2)TY(3)[?]K×K

We can estimate a probabilitic model on Y by factorizing it. This duplication of data enables the factorization to use the data from both document and word in the label embeddings.
